children.name: when a mode of transport leaves
pull out
children.definition: if atrainpulls out, it slowly gains speed as it leaves the station at the start of a journey: rời bến
examples: We got there just as the train was pulling out.
A car pulled right out in front of me.

children.name: go
children.definition: especiallyspokento leave:
examples: Do you know what time the next bus goes?
mainly UKWhat time does the last train to Bath go?

children.name: leave
children.definition: Her plane s Hong Kong at 10.00.
examples: When we arrived at the bus station, the bus had just left.

children.name: depart
children.definition: to leave - used especially inofficialinformationabouttimeswhen trains, planes, buses etc leave: khởi hành
examples: The bus was due to depart at any moment.
depart from
ocean liners arriving at and departing from the island
The 12.15 shuttle service to Atlanta will depart from platform 16.
depart for
The 06:33 Pullman will depart from London Euston from platform 4.
The train departs Waterloo at 09:00 hours on Saturday.
Flights by Air Europe depart Gatwick on Tuesdays.
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually sayleaveorgorather thandepart:
What time does the next planeleave/go?
Sheleft forGermany last week.
Flightsleavefrom Gatwick on Tuesdays.

children.name: slip away
children.definition: slip out/away  to leavequietlyand without beingnoticed:

children.name: lẻn ra ngoài, lẻn đi
examples: ▪ Harriet glanced around, wondering if she could slip out unnoticed.

children.name: slip out/away to do something
examples: ▪ When everyone was busy talking I slipped away to join Beth for a quiet drink.

children.name: sneak off/away/out
children.definition: to leave quietly taking care not to be seen, usually when you want to do sth else: lẻn đi , trốn đi , trốn ra ngoài
examples: Occasionally she and a friend would sneak off during their free study hour.

children.name: sneak off/away/out from
examples: I don’t know what he’s up to, but he sneaks away from work early every Tuesday.
We tried to sneak off from work early.

children.name: sneak off/away/out to
examples: Annie had sneaked out to the bar, hoping that her parents wouldn’t notice she was gone.

children.name: slope off
children.definition: informal to leave somewhere quietly and secretly, especially when you are avoiding work:
examples: ▪ While the manager was away, Brian took the opportunity to slope off home an hour early every day.
slope off to
▪ ‘Where’s Sam?’ ‘I saw him sloping off to the pub half an hour ago.’

children.name: slink away
children.definition: slink off/away  to leave somewhere quietly, without being seen, especially because you are ashamed or afraid:
examples: ▪ Alyssia had dumped her fiancé just two weeks before the wedding, and then slunk off to the south of France.
slinkverb[I usually + adv/prep ]slunk,slunklén, lẩn, lẻn
to walk away from somewhere quietly so that you are not noticed
_I tried to slink out of the room so that nobody would see me go.
_disapprovingHe usually slinksoff(= leaves) at about 3.30.

children.name: force yourself away
children.definition: tear/ to leave aplaceorpersonveryunwillinglybecause youhaveto: ép mình rời khỏi
examples: The view was so magnificent that it was difficult to tear ourselves away.

children.name: tear/force yourself away from
examples: Jake watched as police officers examined the body. It was a horrible sight, but he couldn’t tear himself away from it.

children.name: can’t bear to leave
children.definition: /goalsofind it difficult to leave to feel it is extremely difficult to leave apersonorplacethat youlikevery much:
examples: Kim couldn’t bear to leave Danny, and cried all the way to the airport.
Ballesteros has always found it difficult to leave his home in Pedrena.

children.name: can hardly bearto leave
examples: We’d had such a great vacation, we could hardly bear to leave.

children.name: spoken: telling sb angrily to go away
get lost/push off/ clear off UK
children.definition: said when you want someone to go away because they are annoying you: cút xéo
examples: I’ve told you before that we don’t need our windows cleaning, so just clear off and don’t come back!
Look, just push off will you. You’re getting on my nerves.
Get lost you creep! Stop following me.

children.name: go away
children.definition: I wish you’d all just  and leave me alone!
examples: Major Ferguson opened a window, and shouted to the waiting reporters: ‘You’re wasting your time. Go away!’

children.name: beat it
children.definition: /take a hike US informal said when you want sb to go away because they are annoying you: cút xéo
examples: Beat it, you two. I’ve had enough of you for one day.

children.name: to leave at the start of a journey
go
children.definition: especiallyspokento leave:
examples: Let’s go!
The trip is all planned - we’re going in September.
I’ve packed all my bags, and I’m ready to go.

children.name: leave
children.definition: I have to  early tomorrow morning to fly to Detroit.
examples: Her plane leaves Hong Kong at 10.00.
When are you leaving to go on holiday?
When we arrived at the bus station, the bus had just left.

children.name: leave for/from
examples: I’m leaving for Paris on Tuesday.
Coaches leave from Victoria every hour.

children.name: be off
children.definition: UKinformalto leave and begin a journey:
examples: I think we’d better be off now - it’ll take at least an hour to get to the airport.
drive off [I PV] to quickly start driving a car away from somewhere:
Eddie ran out of the house, jumped into his car, and drove off.
Someone had smashed into her car, and then just driven off.
Adrian just had time to see his father jump into the truck and drive off in a cloud of dust.
I got in the car and drove off.

children.name: be off to
examples: When are you off to Canada?

children.name: I’m off
children.definition: UK /I’m outta hereUS informal
examples: Okay, I’m off now.
Right. I’m off to bed.
That’s it. I’m outta here!

children.name: I must go
children.definition: UK /IgottagoUS said when you have to go somewhere:
examples: Anyway, I gotta go. Catch up with you later.

children.name: I must be going
examples: I must be going. I’ve got to pick the kids up at four.

children.name: I must dash
children.definition: / flyUK said when you have to hurry: phải nhanh
examples: I’ll have another coffee ,and then I must dash.

children.name: I’d better make tracks
children.definition: /I’d better make a moveUK said when you want to start getting ready to leave soon:
examples: We’d better make tracks, or we’ll miss our train.
I think we’d better make a move before it gets dark.

children.name: I’m getting out of here
children.definition: said when you want to leave quickly to avoiddangeror sthunpleasant:
examples: Oh no. It’s him again. I’m getting out of here!

children.name: walk out
children.definition: to leave an event such as a meeting or performance because you are angry or disapprove of sth: bỏ đi, ra về
examples: Furious by now, I walked out, leaving him sitting there shocked and white-faced.
All the parents walked out (ofthe meeting) in protest.

children.name: storm out
children.definition: to leave a room after a quarrel in a very noisy and angry way: lao ra
examples: She yelled at me and stormed out, slamming the door behind her.

children.name: storm out of
examples: He has been known to storm out of meetings on several occasions.
He stormed out of the house, slamming the door as he went.

children.name: flounce out
children.definition: if sb, especially a woman, flounces out of a room, meeting, restaurant etc, she leaves in a way which shows that she is angry or thinks she has been treated unfairly:
examples: ‘I’m not putting up with your sexist comments any more,’ said Gilly, flouncing out.

children.name: flounce out of
examples: She flounced out of the restaurant, got into her car, and drove off into the night.

children.name: to go away from a place
go
children.definition: especially spoken to leave:
examples: Let’s go.
When does the next bus go?
We stayed another ten minutes and then we went.
I’ll have to go soon - was there anything else you wanted to talk about?
Don’t go just yet - it’s not that late!
What time does the last train go?
Right, let’s go!
She turned to go.

children.name: be/get going
examples: It’s late! I must get going.

children.name: leave
children.definition: Just as I was leaving, the phone rang.
examples: I want to see you before I leave.
The police wanted to know what time he had left the office.
Hand back the identity card when you leave the building.

children.name: go away
children.definition: to leave a place, often for alongtime orpermanently: đi xa
examples: I’m going away next week. Would you mind feeding the cat for me?

children.name: ‘Are you going away this summer?’ ‘Yes, we’re going to Greece in August.’
examples: He’s been really unhappy since she went away.
Go away and leave me alone!

children.name: go off
children.definition: to leave a placesuddenlyor for a particular purpose, especially if you donotexplainwhy you are going: cứ thế đi
examples: They just went off, without even saying goodbye.
Many trainees don’t finish the course and go off and work in other areas.

children.name: go off to do sth
examples: When we could not find out what was wrong with the car, Billy went off to find a phone.

children.name: set off
children.definition: /out to start alongjourney or start going somewhere, especially if your journey has been planned or has a special purpose: khởi hành, rời đi
examples: ▪ What time do you have to set off in the morning?
▪ We had meant to set out before lunch but nobody was ready to leave.

children.name: set off/out towards/along/in the direction of etc
examples: ▪ Packing herself a couple of sandwiches, she set off along the cliff path.
▪ The weather had been fine on the morning that the climbers set out up the last part of the mountain.

children.name: set off/out for
examples: ▪ My mother was only twenty when she married my father and set off for Addis Ababa.

children.name: set off/out from
examples: ▪ The Royal Navy set out from Portsmouth on July 13th.

children.name: set off/out to do
examples: ▪ Columbus set out to discover America in the fifteenth century.

children.name: start for
children.definition: to start a journey to a particular place: bắt đầu ( đi đâu )
examples: When are you starting for Seattle?
It was already dark by the time we started for home.

children.name: hit the road
children.definition: to start a journey: lên đường
examples: ▪ It’s time we hit the road.
▪ The group will be hitting the road again in the new year, in order to promote their new album.

children.name: get going
children.definition: /moving informal to start a journey or start going somewhere, especially when you are late or when there has been a delay: lên đường
examples: Let’s get going now or we’ll miss the train.
We'd better get moving or we'll be late.
The coach was supposed to leave at 10:30 but we eventually got going at 3 o'clock.
Get going, you two! Didn’t you hear the school bell?

children.name: start off
children.definition: to start moving away from a place where you have been, especially if you are driving a car, riding a bicycle etc: bắt đầu đi (thường là phương tiện cá nhân)
examples: Before starting off you should check that your seat and mirrors are properly adjusted.

children.name: start off along/towards/down etc
examples: The riders got back on their horses and started off along the track again.

children.name: abandon
children.definition: to go away makes it impossible for you to stay: bỏ đi
examples: We had to abandon the car and walk the rest of the way.
Fearing further attacks, most of the population had abandoned the city.
By the time the rebel troops arrived, the village had already been abandoned.
from a place, vehicle etc permanently, especially because the situation
abandonment[U]
The abandonment of the island followed nuclear tests in the area.
